page.text: This Initial Study of environmental impacts is being prepared to conform to the requirements of the
California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA), the CEQA Guidelines (California Code of
Regulations §15000 et.seq.) and the regulations and policies of the City of Morgan Hill.
This Initial Study evaluates the environmental impacts that might reasonably be anticipated to result
from implementation of the proposed Hale-Signature project. The project proposes a General Plan
amendment to change the land use designation on the 30-acre site from Public Facilities to Single
Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre). For the purposes of this Initial Study, development at
the upper range of the proposed General Plan designation, or up to 150 residential units, is assumed
The applicant has stated an objective to accommodate about 120 dwelling units on the site. Under
Morgan Hill’s current general plan designations and zoning regulations, density is calculated based
on gross site area, and therefore the Single Family Medium designation and R1-7,000 zoning would
be the most appropriate categories to accommodate the applicant’s project objectives.
The City of Morgan Hill has held public hearings and is preparing to adopt a new “Single Family
High” (5-10 units/acre) general plan land use designation and zoning, along with changes to its
definition of lot area to shift from “gross” to “net” as the basis of calculating density. The new
district would allow for lot sizes of less than 7,000 square feet, such as 5,000 and 6,000 square foot
lots with detached single family units. The Hale-Signature project site will need to accommodate the
Madrone Parkway extension and project roads, Fisher Creek and appropriate creek setbacks, on-site
stormwater detention area, and possible buffers from the UPRR and/or possible park area. Therefore,
the net developable area of the 30 gross acre site may be about 22 net acres, and 120 units on 22
acres would be more than 5 units per acre. It is possible that changes to the definitions of the lot
sizes will be made to the zoning code in the near future and the Hale-Signature project could decide
that the preferred method of achieving the project objectives under the City’s new regulations would
be to instead apply the new Single Family High designation and zoning if it is adopted and available
as an option. Currently it is envisioned that the Single Family High designation would have a
minimum lot size of 4,500 square feet.
This Initial Study has assumed a 150-unit project on the site. If a substantially higher number of
dwelling units were to be proposed in the future, then subsequent or supplemental CEQA review will
likely be required to ensure that there are no new or substantially more severe impacts than disclosed
Throughout this Initial Study and in the Transportation Impact Analysis, the description will continue
to reflect the Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre) zoning district, but this will also be
interpreted to include designation as “Single Family High” if that option becomes available and the
applicant modifies the proposed project to that new designation as the preferred method of achieving
the assumed project housing type (about 5 units per gross acre or about 7 units per net acre) that is
The City of Morgan Hill is the Lead Agency under CEQA and has prepared this Initial Study to
address the impacts of implementing the currently proposed project.
The approximately 30-acre project site is located between Hale Avenue and Monterey Road
approximately one-half mile south of the intersection of Tilton Avenue and Hale Avenue in Morgan

text.b: GENERAL PLAN DESIGNATION AND ZONING DISTRICT

page.text: The approximately 30-acre project site is located between Hale Avenue and Monterey Road one-half
mile south of the intersection of Tilton Avenue and Hale Avenue in Morgan Hill, (refer to Figures 1-
3). The site is surrounded by residential development to the north and south, commercial and
industrial development to the east, and unincorporated rural open space to the west. Union Pacific
Railroad (UPRR) tracks run along the eastern border of the site. Fisher Creek is located between
Hale Avenue and the western border of the site.
The project site was annexed by the City of Morgan Hill in 2002. The site was then prezoned Public
Facilities and a General Plan amendment changed the land use designation from Single Family
Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre) to Public Facilities to facilitate the development of a proposed
private high school. The General Plan amendment also approved an extension of Madrone Parkway
southwest to Hale Avenue from its current terminus at Monterey Road. The Madrone Parkway
extension would be a four-lane divided arterial roadway that would include an at-grade crossing over
the UPRR tracks on the eastern edge of the site. The Morgan Hill Catholic High School Final
Environmental Impact Report (MHCHS FEIR), which analyzed these actions, was certified in 2002.
The application to develop the high school has since been withdrawn. The site is currently vacant
and undeveloped, and the Madrone Parkway extension has not been built.
The project proponent proposes a General Plan amendment to change the land use designation on the
site from Public Facilities to Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre)
Figure 4. This will allow 90 to 150 single-family units on the site.

The applicant has stated an objective to accommodate about 120 dwelling units on the site. Under
Morgan Hill’s current general plan designations and zoning regulations, density is calculated based
on gross site area, and therefore the Single Family Medium designation and R1-7,000 zoning would
be the most appropriate categories to accommodate the applicant’s project objectives.
The planned Madrone Parkway extension identified in the city’s Circulation Element will remain
unchanged by the Hale-Signature project application, but it should be recognized that the City of
Morgan Hill is currently studying a General Plan Circulation Element Amendment to modify the
existing planned 4 lane arterial at-grade crossing of the site, to be a 2 lane arterial grade separated
crossing. The General Plan Land Use Amendment and rezoning of the site can accommodate either
circulation network decision, i.e. to keep the General Plan as it currently exists or to amend it with
regard to the planned Madrone Parkway extension improvement.

High (5-10 units/acre)” general plan land use designation and zoning, along with changes to its
definition of lot area to shift from “gross” to “net” as the basis of calculating density. The new
district would allow for lot sizes of less than 7,000 square feet, such as 5,000 and 6,000 square foot
lots with detached single family units. The Hale-Signature project site will need to accommodate the
Madrone Parkway extension and project roads, Fisher Creek and appropriate creek setbacks, on-site
stormwater detention area, and possible buffers from the UPRR and/or possible park area. Therefore,
the net developable area of the 30 gross acre site may be about 22 net acres or even less, and 120
units on 22 acres would be more than 5 units per acre. It is possible that changes to the definitions of
the lot sizes will be made to the zoning code in the near future and the Hale-Signature project could
decide that the preferred method of achieving the project objectives under the City’s new regulations
would be to instead apply the new Single Family High designation and zoning if it is adopted and
available as an option. Currently it is envisioned that the Single-Family High Density zoning district
would have a minimum lot size of 4,500 square feet.
This Initial Study has assumed a 150-unit project on the site. If a substantially higher number of
dwelling units were to be proposed in the future, then subsequent or supplemental CEQA review will
likely be required to ensure that there are no new or substantially more severe impacts than disclosed
Throughout this Initial Study and in the Transportation Impact Analysis, the description will continue
to reflect the Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre) land use designation and zoning
district, but this will also be interpreted to include designation as “Single Family High” if that option
becomes available and the applicant modifies the proposed project to that new designation as the
preferred method of achieving the assumed project housing type (about 5 units per gross acre or
about 7 units per net acre) that is analyzed by this Initial Study. A comparison of the proposed

text.i: This section describes the existing environmental conditions on and near the project area, as well as
environmental impacts associated with the proposed project. The environmental checklist, as
recommended in the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Guidelines, identifies
environmental impacts that could occur if the proposed project is implemented.
The right-hand column in the checklist lists the source(s) for the answer to each question. The
sources cited are identified at the end of this section. Mitigation measures are identified for all
significant project impacts. Measures that are standard and required by the City or law are
categorized as “Standard Measures.” Measures that are required to reduce significant impacts to a
less than significant level are categorized as “Mitigation Measures.”

page.text: The project site is located in northwest Morgan Hill and consists of flat agricultural land at the base
of the Santa Cruz Mountain range foothills. There are no structures on the site and the site has never
been developed. Although the project site itself is undeveloped, it is surrounded by urban
development on three sides. Views of the project site are limited to the immediate vicinity of the
project site. The most noticeable attribute of the project site is the five large oak trees located in the
northern portion of the site which are of a size that is subject to the Significant Tree provisions of the
Morgan Hill Municipal Code. Views of the project site taken from the western boundary, looking
east towards the City of Morgan Hill, are shown in Photos 1 and 2.

site from Public Facilities to Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre)
the future development of up to 150 single family units on the site. While future development would
change the visual character of the site by allowing for the future development of residential
buildings, these structures would be similar in scale to existing residential development in the project
area, to the north and south. New buildings would modify views of foothill areas from both Hale
Avenue and Monterey Road, but are not anticipated to have a substantial adverse effect on a scenic
Future residences would incrementally increase light and glare due to the new building surfaces,
vehicles traveling to and from the development, and lighted buildings and streets. These new sources
of light and glare are not considered substantial and would be consistent with the light and glare
currently created by residential buildings, street lights, and automobiles in residential areas to the
north and south. In addition, future development would be reviewed during the City’s design permit
process for consistency with the City’s design guidelines including the appropriate use of lighting
and avoidance of glare. Implementation of the General Plan amendment, therefore, would not result
in significant, adverse visual or aesthetic impacts.

According to the Santa Clara County Important Farmland 2006 Map, the project site is designated
Farmland of Local Importance. Farmland of Local Importance is defined as small orchards and
vineyards primarily in the foothill areas, and also land cultivated as dry cropland for grains and hay.
The site was used for agricultural purposes since at least the 1950’s, and has been used for dry
farming of hay in recent years. The site, however, has been fallow for a number of years. The site is
not subject to a Williamson Act contract.
The project site is bordered by commercial and industrial land uses beyond the railroad tracks and
Monterey Highway to the east, single family residences to the north and south, and rural open space
across Hale Avenue to the west. There are no agricultural uses located adjacent to the project site.

The project site is currently designated as Farmland of Local Importance, but is not zoned for
agricultural use. The site, which is bordered by residential, commercial, and industrial development
to the north, south, and east, has been dry farmed for hay as recently as 2001. The proposed General
Plan amendment to change the land use designation on the site from Public Facilities to Single
Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre) would allow for the development of up to150
residential units. Although the project would result in the conversion of farmland to a non-
agricultural use, the current land use designation on the site of Public Facilities also allows for
development that would convert farmland to a non-agricultural use. Furthermore, the existing Public
Facilities designation on the site does not allow for agricultural uses as permitted uses and
agriculture is not specifically listed as a conditional use. The Planning Commission could adopt a
conditional use for “any other use which the Planning Commission finds to be of similar nature to the
permitted or conditional uses specified in this chapter for the PF zoning district” (Morgan Hill
Municipal Code, Chapter 18.19), but the project site is located within the city limits and has long
been planned for urban uses. The project would not convert Prime Farmland, Unique Farmland, or
Farmland of Statewide Importance to a non-agricultural use, and would not conflict with existing
zoning for agricultural use or a Williamson Act contract. The site not adjacent to other farmland and
future development would not interfere with other agricultural operations or facilitate the conversion
of farmland elsewhere in the Morgan Hill area to non-agricultural uses. For these reasons, the
project would not result in a significant impact to agricultural resources.
The proposed project would not result in a significant impact to agricultural resources. (Less Than

According to the CEQA Guidelines prepared and adopted by the Bay Area Air Quality Management
District (BAAQMD), the following criteria must be satisfied for a local general plan to be
determined to be consistent with the most current Clean Air Plan (CAP) and to not, therefore, have a
The local plan should be consistent with the CAP population and Vehicle Miles Traveled
(VMT) assumptions. This is demonstrated if the population growth over the planning period
will not exceed the values included in the current CAP; and
The local plan demonstrates reasonable efforts to implement the Transportation Control
Measures (TCMs) included in the CAP that identifies cities as implementing agencies.
The proposed General Plan amendment would allow residential development on the parcel. A
maximum of 150 dwelling units could be constructed on the project site under the proposed land use.
While the General Plan amendment would facilitate residential growth in Morgan Hill, residential
growth in Morgan Hill is ultimately controlled by the Residential Development Control System
(RDCS). By approving Measure C in 2004, Morgan Hill voters extended the City’s RDCS to 2020.
The General Plan assumes that some form of residential growth control and the current allowed rate
of about 250 new units per year will continue until 2020, with the end result being a city population
of 48,000, which is slightly below ABAG Projections 2003 and what is assumed in the 2005 CAP.
The General Plan also includes policies to implement identified TCMs. For these reasons,
population growth over the planning period will be consistent with the CAP population and VMT
assumptions and, therefore, would not result in a significant long-term regional air quality impact.
Construction-related air quality impacts associated with activities generating dust such as excavation
and grading operations could occur with the future development of residences on the site. The City
of Morgan Hill requires implementation of standard dust control measures (below).

text.b: City of Morgan Hill Standard Measure

page.text: In accordance with the City of Morgan Hill Standard Conditions of approval, prior to issuance of a
building permit, the owner shall submit to the Planning Division for approval, a management plan
detailing strategies for control of dust during construction of the project. The intent of this condition
is to minimize construction related disturbance of residents of the nearby or adjacent properties.

i.b: Measures to be Considered at the Time of Future Development

page.text: The Bay Area Air Quality Management District (BAAQMD) has prepared a list of feasible
construction dust control measures that can reduce construction impacts to a level that is less than
significant. These measures are listed in the BAAQMD CEQA Guidelines. At the time any future
development is considered, these measures, or equivalent measures, should be required as conditions
of approval to reduce the generation of construction dust. Short-term air quality impacts associated
with construction could be reduced to less than significant levels with the implementation of standard
construction measures and mitigation measures identified in the BAAQMD Guidelines.
The proposed project would not result in significant long-term regional or local air quality impacts.
While possible future uses could result in temporary air quality impacts during construction, it is
assumed that General Plan policies (and mitigation measures recommended in the BAAQMD CEQA
Guidelines) would reduce impacts to a less than significant level. (Less Than Significant Impact)
The following discussion is based upon a Biological Resources Report prepared in August 2001 by
H.T. Harvey & Associates for the MHCHS FEIR.
Four biotic habitats, as well as developed habitat, were identified on the site. The biotic habitats are
agricultural, ruderal, seasonal drainage, and perennial wetlands. These habitats are described below
and their locations can be seen on Figure 5.
Most of the 30-acre project site was formerly utilized for agricultural purposes, including hay
production. Dominant grasses in the hay field are wheat and wild oats. Other species identified
within the agricultural field include annual ryegrass, meadow barley, California burclover, redstem
filaree, black mustard, bristly ox-tongue, yellow star thistle, English plantain, field bindweed, and
American vetch. In addition, five large oak trees were identified within the agricultural field.
Many wildlife species will use this type of habitat when the vegetation is tall. Once it has been cut,
however, cover and forage are reduced. Bird species such as the red-winged blackbird and song
sparrow will nest in the fields when the vegetation is tall, and will use the field for foraging all year.
The ruderal vegetation around the perimeter of the site increases wildlife use, because it provides
cover for species that may forage there or in open fields, including mourning dove, European
starling, and northern mockingbird. Norway rats and black rats will forage in agricultural fields.
Many of the species listed below under ruderal habitat also use agricultural fields for foraging.
Two patches of ruderal habitat exist along the inside of the western fence line of the project site.
Pieces of scrap iron have been placed in these small patches and, as a result, these areas are not used
for hay production. Ruderal habitat also exists along the eastern edge of Hale Avenue, and on both
sides of a 150-foot long segment of the Union Pacific Railroad tracks, as shown on Figure 5.
Ruderal habitat includes Italian thistle, fiddleneck, ryegrass, meadow barley, California burclover,
wild oat, black mustard, and bristly ox-tongue.
Mammals using this habitat include black-tailed hares, western harvest mouse, California voles, and
house mice. California ground squirrels and Botta’s pocket gophers burrow within the ruderal
habitat, where they are protected from agricultural activities. Gopher snakes and western fence
lizards will make use of these mammal burrows for shelter and reproduction. Bird species include

text.b: otential W aters of the U.S.

page.text: those listed for the agricultural lands, above, as well as killdeer, American goldfinch, and house
A seasonal drainage (Fisher Creek) is located along the entire length of the western boundary of the
project site. The total area of this habitat type within the project site is approximately 0.52 acres.
Although the drainage was dry at the time of the field survey, there is evidence of past high flows,
including debris within the vegetation and water-stained vegetation. The majority of species
identified within the seasonal drainage are more commonly associated with upland non-native
grassland habitat. These species include wild oat, bristly ox-tongue, field bindweed, and American
vetch. The channel bed does contain sparse cover of several wetland species associated with more
water related habitats, including nutsedge, rush, willow herb, spikerush, and curly dock. In addition,
several shrub species were identified along the banks of the drainage including Himalayan
blackberry, silver wattle, and coyote brush.
Much of the vegetation in the drainage channel offers similar habitat for wildlife species as the
ruderal vegetation does, however, the presence of shrub species increases habitat value through
increased forage, shelter, and nesting opportunities. Species such as bushtits, Anna’s hummingbirds,
and house finches will nest in these types of shrubs. Pacific tree frogs will use the shrubs and other
vegetation all year for shelter, but will also use the drainage during the wet season for breeding sites.
The project site supports 0.03 acres of perennial wetland habitat. It is located in the southernmost
extent of the seasonal drainage, in the southwest corner of the project site (as shown on Figure 5).
Dominant species identified within the wetland habitat include narrow-leaved cattail, willow-herb,
curly dock, American sloughgrass, ditch beard grass, nutsedge, rush, and canary grass.
Although this wetland area is small, it offers habitat to a wide variety of wildlife species. Red-
winged blackbirds, marsh wrens, and song sparrows may be found here during the winter migration,
and may even nest in this habitat. While flooded, this habitat provides wintering habitat for
American pipits as well as many other wintering and migrating songbirds. Western meadowlarks,
barn swallows, and great egrets will forage in this habitat. When flooded, many species of ducks and
herons, such as great-blue herons could forage in these wetlands.
Special-status plant and animal species include federal and State of California listed threatened and
endangered species, federal and state proposed, candidate, threatened or endangered species, State of
California fully protected species, and species that may be considered endangered or rare under
Section 15380(d) of the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA). Several special-status plant
and animal species have been identified as historically or currently occurring in the vicinity of the
project site, according to the California Native Plant Society (CNPS) inventory and the California
Natural Diversity Database (CNDDB). Expanded descriptions are included below only for those
species for which potential breeding habitat occurs on the project site, for which specific surveys
have been completed, or for which the resource agencies have expressed particular concern.
Most of the special status plant species that occur in the vicinity of the project site are found in
habitat types that are not present on the project site. There is only one special status plant species
that may occur on the site, Congdon’s tarplant.
Congdon’s tarplant generally occurs on alkaline soils within valley and foothill grassland habitat.
The California Department of Fish and Game (CDFG) Rarefind Database shows no occurrences of
this species within the project vicinity. The blooming period of this annual herb is from June through
November. This species was not detected during reconnaissance level surveys completed within the
blooming period in 2001, however, further surveys for this species are warranted during August and
Reconnaissance level field surveys were completed on the site in early June 2001 for any special
status wildlife species, or habitats capable of supporting such species. There are several special
status animal species known to occur in habitats that are present on the site or that may forage in the
project area, but are not expected to breed on site and therefore, will not be significantly impacted by
site development. These special status species include sharp-shinned hawk, cooper’s hawk, golden
eagle, merlin, California yellow warbler, long-eared owl, California horned lark, and the pallid bat.
Several special status animal species are known to occur in the area, but are thought to be absent
from the project site due to a lack of habitat, or are thought or known to occur only rarely as stray
migrants or transients. Therefore, the project is not expected to result in significant impacts to these
species. These include the American peregrine falcon, Townsend’s big-eared bat, California tiger
salamander, and the California red-legged frog.
Expanded descriptions are included below for those species for which potentially suitable breeding
habitat occurs on the project site. Marginally suitable habitat for nesting raptors and loggerhead
shrike is located on and adjacent to the project site in ruderal habitat and in the large oak trees, as
The northern harrier is commonly found in open grasslands, agricultural areas, and marshes. Nests
are built on the ground in areas where long grasses provide cover and protection. Harriers hunt for a
variety of prey, including rodents, birds, frogs, reptiles, and insects, by flying low and slow in a
traversing manner utilizing both sight and sound to detect prey. Northern harriers have been
observed in the project vicinity and potential nesting habitat for this species occurs in the tall
herbaceous vegetation adjacent to the site or within ruderal habitat on the site.
White-tailed kites prefer habitats with low ground cover and variable tree growth. Kite nests are
built near the tops of oaks, willows, or other dense broad-leafed deciduous trees in partially cleared
or cultivated fields, grassy foothills, marsh, riparian, woodland, and savannah. Kites prey primarily
on small rodents (especially California vole), but also feed on birds, insects, reptiles, and amphibians.
When prey is abundant, these birds may rear two broods in a single breeding season. Once
considered endangered in the State, the fully protected kite is now fairly common. White-tailed kites
have been observed in the project vicinity, and suitable breeding habitat exists in the taller trees on
The saltmarsh common yellowthroat is currently a California Species of Special Concern. This
species inhabits emergent vegetation and breeds in freshwater and brackish marshes and associated
upland areas in the San Francisco Bay Area. This species often produces two clutches per year with
breeding populations recorded in marshes in San Mateo, San Francisco, Napa, Sonoma, Solano,
Marin, and Santa Clara Counties. The saltmarsh common yellowthroat breeds in bayside marshes
and nearby associated riparian and scrubby vegetation. The extent that this species occurs upstream
before being replaced by a more widespread subspecies in the South Bay is unclear. It is not possible
to identify this species in the field without collecting them, however, there is marginal breeding and
foraging habitat on the site. Therefore, this species could be present on the site.
The burrowing owl is a small, terrestrial owl of open country. Burrowing owls favor flat, open
grassland or gentle slopes and sparse shrubland ecosystems. These owls prefer annual and perennial
grasslands, typically with sparse, or nonexistent, tree or shrub canopies. In California, burrowing
owls are found in close association with California ground squirrels. Owls use ground squirrel
burrows for shelter and nesting. In the absence of ground squirrel populations, habitats soon become
unsuitable for occupancy by owls. The nesting season burrowing owl, as recognized by the CDFG,
As habitats become surrounded by human development, they become increasingly inhospitable to
burrowing owls. Burrowing owl populations are thought to be declining throughout much of their
range in the United States and Canada. Loss of habitat and campaigns against ground squirrels are
suspected causes of this decline. In California, the burrowing owl has been designated as a Species
of Special Concern, due to diminishing habitats and concurrent population declines.
Reconnaissance-level surveys were completed on the site for burrowing owls. While no owls or
evidence of use of the site by owls were found, owls are known to be located within the project area.
The site characteristics are consistent with nesting and/or foraging habitat for burrowing owls.
The loggerhead shrike is a predatory bird that forages in grasslands or ruderal habitats for small
reptiles, mammals, birds, and insects and nests in small trees and shrubs. In approximately the last
20 years, populations of loggerhead shrike in eastern North America have declined significantly.
Although loggerhead shrikes are still considered a fairly common species in much of California, the
piecemeal loss of grasslands has caused local declines in many areas, and the species as a whole is
Loggerhead shrikes have been observed on and adjacent to the project site. Suitable nesting and
foraging habitat for this species, which includes trees and shrubs with an understory of herbaceous
vegetation, is present on the site.
A reconnaissance-level survey of the site was completed in August 2001 for areas that meet the
regulatory definition of Waters of the United States (jurisdictional waters). Potential wetlands were
identified at the southernmost end of the seasonal drainage (Fisher Creek) located in the southwest
corner of the project site, as shown on Figure 5. These potential wetlands are dominated by plants
that either prefer or require water. The total surface area of these wetlands is 0.03 acres. Tributary
waters, as defined by the ordinary high water (OHW) mark on opposing channel banks of the

i.b: California Department of Fish and Game Jurisdiction

page.text: The project site was examined for those areas within the bed, bank, and channel of the seasonal
drainages that are under the regulatory jurisdiction of the CDFG. These areas generally include
rivers, streams, creeks, or lakes. In addition, canals, aqueducts, irrigation ditches, and other means of
water conveyance can also be considered streams if they support aquatic life, riparian vegetation, or
Based on the physical characteristics of the site, the criteria used to identify CDFG jurisdiction was
the top-of-bank or opposing channel banks of Fisher Creek. Approximately 1.19 acres of potential
CDFG jurisdictional habitat was identified along the seasonal drainage, including 0.03 acres of
wetland habitat, as shown on Figure 5.
The City of Morgan Hill Restrictions on Removal of Significant Trees defines a significant tree as
non-native trees equal to or greater than 40 inches in circumference and native trees equal to or
greater than 18 inches in circumference. All trees are to be measured at 4.5 feet above the ground or
immediately below the lowest branch, whichever is lowest. A tree removal permit from the City of
Morgan Hill, or approval to remove trees as part of an approved development plan, is required for the
A tree survey completed on the site identified a total of five oak trees. All of these trees are

i.b: Santa Clara Valley Habitat Conservation Plan/Natural Community Conservation

page.text: A HCP/NCCP is currently being prepared for the Santa Clara Valley. The Santa Clara Valley
HCP/NCCP is a regional partnership between six local partners (the County of Santa Clara, Santa
Clara Valley Transportation Authority, Santa Clara Valley Water District, and the Cities of San Jose,
Gilroy and Morgan Hill) and three wildlife agencies (the California Department of Fish and Game,
the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, and the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS-NOAA
Fisheries). The HCP/NCCP process is anticipated to be completed in 2010.
The HCP/NCCP will address listed species and species that are likely to become listed during the
plan’s 50-year permit term. The species of concern include, but are not limited to, the California tiger
salamander, California red-legged frog, western burrowing owl, Bay checkerspot butterfly, and a
number of species endemic to serpentine grassland and scrub. An administrative draft version of the
HCP/NCCP is currently available for review.
Of the 30 species currently being considered in the
Habitat Plan, several species may be present in the project vicinity. These include, but are not
limited to, burrowing owl, big-scale balsamroot, golden eagle, and Townsend’s western big-eared
Source: 2nd Administrative Draft Santa Clara Valley HCP/NCCP, June 1, 2009.

Future construction of residential units on the project site would result in the conversion of
approximately 30 acres of agricultural habitat into developed land. The flora associated with this
habitat is common and regionally abundant. The loss of dry-farmed agricultural habitat is not likely
to adversely affect any wildlife species, as the site has been actively cultivated and/or disturbed by
vegetation removal for weed abatement and fire management purposes on a regular basis. The loss
of agricultural habitat would, therefore, be a less than significant impact. The loss of this habitat
would, however, result in the loss of burrowing owl habitat, as discussed below.
Ruderal habitat identified within the project site is well represented in the project area. The flora
associated with this habitat is common throughout the region. In addition, most wildlife species
associated with ruderal habitats are common throughout the region, with the exception of burrowing
owls and loggerhead shrike. Impacts to these species are considered separately, below. Therefore,
the loss of this habitat is considered a less than significant impact.
Most of the special-status plants that occur in regional habitats similar to those found on site were
dismissed as potentially occurring, due to the absence of characteristic habitat and/or microhabitat
requirements. The only species regarded as potentially occurring on-site is Congdon’s tarplant,
however, protocol-level surveys have not yet been completed to confirm its presence or absence.
Future development on the site could result in significant impacts to Congdon’s tarplant.
Impact BIO-1: Future residential development on the site could result in significant impacts to

Raptors (northern harrier and white-tailed kite) and loggerhead shrike, and their nests are protected
under both federal and state laws and regulations. Marginally suitable breeding sites for nesting

construction activities on the site could result in the destruction of nests and/or disturbance of nesting

Reconnaissance-level surveys were completed in 2001 that determined there are no burrowing owls
on the site. The site characteristics are, however, consistent with burrowing owl nesting and foraging
habitat, and owls are known to occur in the project area. Therefore, disturbances associated with
future construction on the site during the breeding season could result in the incidental loss of fertile
eggs or nestlings or otherwise lead to nest abandonment. The destruction of occupied burrowing owl
burrows could also result in the destruction of individual birds. Any loss of burrowing owls or fertile
eggs, any activities resulting in nest abandonment, or the destruction of occupied burrowing owl
burrows would constitute a significant impact. Future development on the project site would also
result in the loss of burrowing owl nesting and foraging habitat within the project area and the City of

Future development on the site may result in the loss of up to five native ordinance-size oak trees, as

text.b: City of Morgan Hill General Plan

page.text: Various policies in the City’s General Plan were adopted for the purpose of avoiding or mitigating
impacts to biological resources resulting from planned development within the City. All future
development is subject to General Plan policies, including the following, which would reduce or
Plants and Wildlife Policy 6a – Preserve all fish and wildlife habitats in their natural state
whenever possible. Consider development impacts upon wildlife and utilize actions to
Plants and Wildlife Policy 6c - Preserve outstanding natural features, such as the skyline of a
prominent hill, rock outcroppings, and native and/or historically significant trees.
Plants and Wildlife Policy 6e - Identify and protect wildlife, rare and endangered plants and
animals and heritage resources from loss and destruction.
Plants and Wildlife Policy 6g - Encourage use of native plants, especially drought-resistant
species in landscaping to the extent possible.
Water Quality Policy 6f – Require the protection and/or replacement of essential habitat for
rare, threatened, or endangered species and species of special concern as required by state
Water Quality Policy 6g – Encourage the protection, restoration, and enhancement of
remaining native grasslands, oak woodlands, marshlands, and riparian habitat.
Water Quality Policy 6h – Preserve and protect mature, healthy trees whenever feasible,
particularly native trees and other trees which are of significant size or of significant aesthetic
value to immediate vicinity or to the community as a whole.

project site will be required to implement the following measures to avoid direct impacts to
burrowing owls and to offset impacts to non-native grassland habitat. Implementation of this
standard measure would avoid or reduce significant impacts to burrowing owls and their habitat.
Complete pre-construction surveys to determine if burrowing owls are present within the
footprint of the proposed grading area, no more than 30 days prior to initiation of any
Should burrowing owls be found on the site during breeding season (February 1 through
August 31), exclusion zones with a 250-foot radius from occupied burrows, shall be
established. All project-related activities shall occur outside the exclusion area until the
If preconstruction surveys are completed during the non-breeding season and burrowing owls
are observed on the site, the owls may be relocated upon approval of the California
Department of Fish and Game once mitigation has been provided.
A final report on burrowing owls, including any protection measures, shall be submitted to
the Director of Community Development prior to grading.

No building shall be constructed within 50 feet of a perennial or intermittent stream [Morgan

In July 2005, the Morgan Hill City Council adopted an interim City Council policy that applies to

City Council Policy 05-02 - New development adjacent to streams and waterways shall be
designed to preserve and integrate the waterways and associated habitats. New development
should respect the water resource as an asset to the development, and shall not wall off the
stream or waterway. New development shall incorporate open space buffers adjacent to

within the open space buffer, either as reflected in the City's Park and Bikeways Master Plan
or when reasonable and appropriate. Conditions of approval may be imposed to require
restoration of riparian habitat, as feasible.
This policy shall apply to land adjacent to streams and waterways which have value as
natural and/or recreational resources, including Llagas, West Little Llagas, Edmundson,
Fisher, Tennant, Corralitos and Coyote Creeks, as well as the Madrone and Butterfield

text.b: Federal and State Laws and Regulations Protecting Wetlands and Creeks

page.text: Section 401 and 404 of the Federal Clean Water Act
At the federal level, the Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. 1344) is the primary law regulating impacts to
wetlands and waters. The Clean Water Act regulates the discharge of dredged or fill material into
waters of the United States, including wetlands. Waters of the United States include navigable
waters, interstate waters, territorial seas, and other waters that may be used in the interstate or foreign
commerce. The Section 404 permit program is run by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (ACOE)
with oversight from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Future impacts to regulated
wetlands or waters due to construction will require conformance with an ACOE permit and
mitigation requirements to offset impacts. Prior to any construction activities, including filling or
excavation within waters of the United States, a Section 404 permit will be obtained from the ACOE
and a Water Quality Certification would be obtained from the Regional Water Quality Control Board
(RWQCB). The RWQCBs were established under the Porter-Cologne Water Quality Act to oversee
water quality in the State of California and the RWQCB issues water quality certification in
compliance with Section 401 of the Clean Water Act where impacts to wetlands are proposed.
Potential Waters of the United States on the project site include perennial wetland associated with
Fisher Creek located in southwestern portion of the site.
The California Fish and Game Code includes regulations governing the use of or impacts to many of
the state’s fish, wildlife, and sensitive habitats. The California Department of Fish and Game
(CDFG) exerts jurisdiction over the bed and banks of rivers, lakes, and streams according to
provisions of Section 1601 through 1603 of the Fish and Game Code. The Fish and Game Code
requires a Streambed Alteration Agreement for the fill or removal of material within the bed and
banks of a watercourse or water body and for the removal of riparian vegetation. Future
development on the site will be required to conform to the requirements of Fish and Game Code and
replacement habitat will be required where there are impacts to riparian vegetation.

text.b: Federal and State Laws and Regulations Protecting Migratory and Nesting Birds

page.text: The federal Migratory Bird Treaty (MBTA; 16 U.SC., Section 703, Supplement I, 1989) prohibits the
killing, possessing, or trading of migratory birds except in accordance with regulations prescribed by
the Secretary of the Interior. The trustee agency that addresses issues related to the MBTA is the
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS). Migratory birds protected under this law include all native
birds and certain game birds (e.g., turkeys and pheasants). This act encompasses whole birds, parts
of birds, and bird nests and eggs. The MBTA protects active nests (i.e., contains eggs or fledglings)
from destruction and all nests of species protected by the MBTA. All native bird species occurring
in the City of Morgan Hill are protected by the MBTA.
All native bird species that occur on the project site are protected by the Fish and Game Code. The
California Fish and Game Code protects native birds, including their nests and eggs, from all forms
of take, which includes disturbance that causes nest abandonment and/or loss of the reproductive
effort. Raptors (i.e., eagles, hawks, falcons, and owls) and their nests are specifically protected in
California under Fish and Game Code section 3503.5. Section 3503.5 states that it is “unlawful to
take, possess, or destroy any birds in the order of Falconiformes or Stringiformes (birds of prey) or to
take, possess, or destroy the nest or eggs of any such bird except as otherwise provided in this code
or regulation adopted pursuant thereto.” Future development on the project site may be required to
include measures to avoid impacts to nesting birds.

mitigation measures need to be implemented for project-related impacts.

direct and indirect impacts to Congdon’s tarplant. This would be done after

a buffer zone would be created during and after construction which is large enough to
eliminate potential disturbance to the plants from human activity and any other
potential sources. Temporary fences would be constructed between the development
If the project cannot be designed to avoid significant impacts to a plant population,

If the implementation of a Site Restoration Plan is not possible, an off site area or

text.b: Measures to Avoid Impacts to Nesting Raptors and Loggerhead Shrike

page.text: Implementation of the following mitigation measures at the time of future development could reduce
impacts to nesting raptors and loggerhead shrike to a less than significant level:
Construction should be scheduled to avoid the nesting season to the extent feasible. The
nesting season for most raptors in the South San Francisco Bay area extends from January
through August. Therefore, if construction can be scheduled to occur between September
and December, the nesting season would be avoided, and no impacts would be expected. If it
is not possible to schedule construction outside of the breeding season, then the following
Pre-construction surveys for nesting raptors and shrikes should be completed by a qualified
ornithologist or wildlife biologist to ensure that no nests would be disturbed during project
construction. This survey should be completed no more than 14 days prior to the initiation of
construction activities during the early part of the breeding season (January through April)
and no more than 30 days prior to the initiation of these activities during the late part of the
breeding season (May through August). During this survey, a qualified biologist should
inspect all trees on and immediately adjacent to the impact areas for nests. If an active nest is
found close enough to the construction area to be disturbed by these activities (250 feet), the
ornithologist, in consultation with CDFG, should determine the extent of a construction-free
buffer zone to be established around the nest.
Trees on the project site should be removed during the non-nesting season after pre-
construction surveys are completed to ensure that nesting raptors and/or their nests would not
be adversely affected as a result of the project.
Implementation of the following mitigation measures at the time of future development could reduce
impacts to breeding yellowthroats to a less than significant level:
Saltmarsh common yellowthroats nest from early March to mid-August. If construction in
proximity to potential nesting habitat can be scheduled to occur between mid-August through
February, the nesting season would be avoided, and no impacts to nesting yellowthroats
would occur. Further, it is recommended that all vegetation be cleared during the non-
breeding season if construction is to occur between early March and mid-August. The site
should be maintained during the construction period so no vegetation is present for nesting
yellowthroats. If vegetation is removed, no impacts to nesting yellowthroats would be
If construction does commence between February through mid-August near potential nesting
habitat, preconstruction surveys for nesting saltmarsh common yellowthroats would be
conducted by a qualified ornithologist in order to ensure that no nests or colonies are
disturbed. The surveys for saltmarsh common yellowthroats would occur no more than 15
days prior to the initiation of construction. If common yellowthroat nests are found to be
present within or near the construction impact areas, a construction-free buffer around any
active nest would be established, the width of this buffer being determined by an experienced
ornithologist in consultation with the CDFG. This buffer would be respected until nesting
Implementation of the General Plan policies and program mitigation measures above would avoid or
mitigate substantial impacts to biological resources at the time of possible future development. (Less

review was completed in 2001 by Holman & Associates, Archaeological Consultants at the
Northwest Information Center, located at the Sonoma State University campus. The literature review

A field inspection of the project site was completed by walking over the entire site to inspect it for
surficial evidence of prehistoric cultural resources. Special attention was paid to the western
boundary of the site along Fisher Creek. There was no evidence of either historic or prehistoric
archaeological resources found on the project site. The historic site located just north of the project
site does not visibly extend into the project area.

text.b: City of Morgan Hill Municipal Code

page.text: In accordance with the City of Morgan Hill Municipal Code Chapter 18.75, proposals for the
development of a site identified as archaeologically sensitive by the City’s adopted archaeological
sensitivity map shall be subject to the following review process and standard conditions of project
The City will consult with the Northwest Information Center for information about whether
proposed development is located within or adjacent to a known archaeological site, and if it is
determined that it is so located, then a historical alteration permit is required for the project,
and subsequent CEQA review of the project shall consider potentially significant impacts on
archaeological resources and identify appropriate mitigation measures to be imposed as
conditions of approval in addition to the standard conditions identified below.
If the project is not located within or adjacent to a known archaeological site, but is located
within the mapped archaeologically sensitive area as adopted by the City, then the project
applicant has the option to either have an archaeological survey be completed for the site to
determine what, if any, conditions of approval will be required as mitigation measures; or
agree to comply with the following standard conditions of approval, which shall be
conclusively deemed to reduce potentially significant impacts on archaeological resources to
a less than significant level (no archaeological resources report is required as part of any
CEQA review of the project as long as the applicant accepts these conditions and
An archaeologist shall be present on-site to monitor all ground-disturbing activities.
Where historical or archaeological artifacts are found, work in areas where remains or
artifacts are found will be restricted or stopped until proper protocols are met, as
Work at the location of the find will halt immediately within thirty feet of the
find. If an archaeologist is not present at the time of the discovery, the
applicant shall contact an archaeologist for evaluation of the find to determine
whether it qualifies as a unique archaeological resource as defined by this
If the find is determined not to be a Unique Archaeological Resource,
construction can continue. The archaeologist will prepare a brief informal
memo/letter that describes and assesses the significance of the resource,
including a discussion of the methods used to determine significance for the
If the find appears significant and to qualify as a unique archaeological
resource, the archaeologist will determine if the resource can be avoided and
will detail avoidance procedures in a formal memo/letter; and
If the resource cannot be avoided, the archaeologist shall develop within
forty-eight hours an action plan to avoid or minimize impacts. The field crew
shall not proceed until the action plan is approved by the community
development director. The action plan shall be in conformance with
All development projects located within an archaeological sensitivity area and/or containing
known archaeological resources on-site shall also be subject to the following measures as
This project may adversely impact undocumented human remains or unintentionally
discover significant historic or archaeological materials. The following policies and
procedures for treatment and disposition of inadvertently discovered human remains
or archaeological materials shall apply. If human remains are discovered, it is
probable they are the remains of Native Americans.
If human remains are encountered they shall be treated with dignity and
respect as due to them. Discovery of Native American remains is a very
sensitive issue and serious concern. Information about such a discovery shall
be held in confidence by all project personnel on a need to know basis. The
rights of Native Americans to practice ceremonial observances on sites, in
labs and around artifacts shall be upheld.
Remains should not be held by human hands. Surgical gloves should be worn
if remains need to be handled.
Surgical mask should also be worn to prevent exposure to pathogens that may
In the event that known or suspected Native American remains are encountered or
significant historic or archaeological materials are discovered, ground-disturbing
activities shall be immediately stopped. Examples of significant historic or
archaeological materials include, but are not limited to, concentrations of historic
artifacts (e.g., bottles, ceramics) or prehistoric artifacts (chipped chert or obsidian,
arrow points, groundstone mortars and pestles), culturally altered ash-stained midden
soils associated with pre-contact Native American habitation sites, concentrations of
fire-altered rock and/or burned or charred organic materials, and historic structure
remains such as stone-lined building foundations, wells or privy pits. Ground-
disturbing project activities may continue in other areas that are outside the exclusion
An “exclusion zone” where unauthorized equipment and personnel are not permitted
shall be established (e.g., taped off) around the discovery area plus a reasonable
buffer zone by the Contractor Foreman or authorized representative, or party who
made the discovery and initiated these protocols, or if on-site at the time or discovery,
by the Monitoring Archaeologist (typically 25-50ft for single burial or archaeological
The exclusion zone shall be secured (e.g., 24 hour surveillance) as directed by the
City or County if considered prudent to avoid further disturbances.
The Contractor Foreman or authorized representative, or party who made the
discovery and initiated these protocols shall be responsible for immediately
contacting by telephone the parties listed below to report the find and initiate the
consultation process for treatment and disposition:
The City of Morgan Hill Community Development Director
The Coroner of the County of Santa Clara (if human remains found)
The Native American Heritage Commission (NAHC) in Sacramento
The Coroner has two working days to examine the remains after being notified of the
discovery. If the remains are Native American the Coroner has 24 hours to notify the
The NAHC is responsible for identifying and immediately notifying the Most Likely
Descendant (MLD) from the Amah Mutsun Tribal Band. (Note: NAHC policy holds
that the Native American Monitor will not be designated the MLD.)
Within 24 hours of their notification by the NAHC, the MLD will be granted
permission to inspect the discovery site if they so choose.
Within 24 hours of their notification by the NAHC, the MLD may recommend to the
City’s community development director the recommended means for treating or
disposing, with appropriate dignity, the human remains and any associated grave
goods. The recommendation may include the scientific removal and non-destructive
or destructive analysis of human remains and items associated with Native American
burials. Only those osteological analyses or DNA analyses recommended by the
Amah Mutsun Tribal Band may be considered and carried out.
If the MLD recommendation is rejected by the City of Morgan Hill the parties will
attempt to mediate the disagreement with the NAHC. If mediation fails then the
remains and all associated grave offerings shall be reburied with appropriate dignity
on the property in a location not subject to further subsurface disturbance.
Implementation of these standard measures would ensure that development allowed under the
proposed General Plan amendment would not result in significant impacts to archaeological
Implementation of the standard measures and laws and regulations listed above, including the
Morgan Hill Municipal Code, would avoid possible impacts to buried archaeological resources from
future development on the site. (Less Than Significant Impact)
According to the City of Morgan Hill’s Geology, Geologic, and Geological Hazards Study, soils on
the majority of the project site consist of unconsolidated colluvium, valley floor alluvium, or terrace
deposits on flat or nearly flat ground. Soils of this type may be subject to settlement under seismic or
aseismic conditions. Small portions of the northwestern and southern corners of the site contain soils
consisting of moderately to highly expansive alluvial or colluvial soil on flat or nearly flat ground.
Soils of this type may be subject to seasonal shrinking and swelling, soil creep, and settlement. Soils
on the western boundary of the site in the immediate vicinity of Fisher Creek are classified as
naturally infilled stream channels and fill placed without geotechnical control that occupy flat or
nearly flat ground. Soils of this type may be subject to vertical settlement. The entire site is
classified as valley floor terrain where ground water has been measured at least once, since about
1950, to be within 15 feet of the ground surface.
Most of soils on the site are described in Soils of Santa Clara County (1968) as Pleasanton loam.
Pleasanton loam has a moderate potential for expansion. Soils on the western boundary of the site, in
the immediate vicinity of Fisher Creek, are described as Los Osos clay loam (LoF). Los Osos clay
loam has a high potential for expansion. Expansive soils shrink and swell as a result of moisture
changes. These changes can cause heaving and cracking of slabs-on-grade, pavements and structures
found on shallow foundations. Because the site topography is flat, there is no erosion or landslide
The San Francisco Bay Area is one of the most seismically active regions in the United States. An
earthquake of moderate to high magnitude generated within the San Francisco Bay region could
cause considerable ground shaking at the project site. The degree of shaking is dependent on the
magnitude of the event, the distance to its zone of rupture and local geologic conditions.
The three major faults in the region are the San Andreas Fault, the Calaveras Fault, and the Hayward
Fault. The San Andreas Fault runs north/south and parallel to the Hayward Fault and the Calaveras
Fault. The San Andreas Fault is approximately 10 miles west of the site, the Calaveras Fault is
approximately four miles east of the site, and the Hayward Fault is approximately 10 miles northeast
of the site. The project site is not located within a fault rupture zone.
U.S. Geological Survey and California Geological Survey, Quaternary Fault and Fold Database for the United
Soil liquefaction is a condition where saturated granular soils near the ground surface undergo a
substantial loss of strength during seismic events. Loose, water-saturated soils are transformed from
a solid to a liquid state during ground shaking. Liquefaction can result in significant deformations.
Soils most susceptible to liquefaction are loose, uniformly graded, saturated, fine-grained sands that
lie close to the ground surface. According to the City of Morgan Hill’s Geology, Geologic, and
Geological Hazards Study, the entire site is classified as valley floor terrain where ground water has
been measured at least once, since about 1950, to be within 15 feet of the ground surface. Areas of
potential shallow groundwater are also areas of potential soil liquefaction.

Environmental Hazards Policy 1a – Limit uses on lands with geologic hazards.

Environmental Hazards Policy 1d – Known or potential geologic, fire, and flood hazards
should be reported as part of every real estate transaction, as well as recordation on
documents to be reported for building permits, subdivisions and land development reports.
Mitigation of hazards should be noted in the same manner.
Environmental Hazards Policy 1g – New development should avoid hazardous and sensitive

habitable structures should not be allowed in areas of highest hazard such as floodways,
active landslides, active fault traces, and airport safety zones. In areas of less risk,
development should be limited and designed to reduce risks to an acceptable level. (SCJAP
Environmental Hazards Policy 1k – Regulate development in hazardous areas in such a way
that it minimizes disruption of the environment and does not trigger or accelerate the

Environmental Hazards Policy 1n – Cluster development in hazardous areas with dwellings
grouped on the least hazardous portion of the property. (SCJAP 15.02e)
Environmental Hazards Actions 1.1 – Continue to require geologic studies for development

Implementation of the General Plan policies and standard measures discussed above would avoid
geology and soil impacts at the time of future development on the site. (Less Than Significant
The following discussion is based upon a Phase I Site Assessment and a Soil Sampling and Analysis
Report prepared for the project site by E2C, Inc. in September 2000 and July 2001, respectively.
A review of available historical aerial photographs revealed that the site has been in agricultural
production since before at least 1950, and it has never been developed. This was confirmed in
conversations with the property owner who has personal knowledge of uses on the site for the 20
years prior to completion of the Phase I Site Assessment.
During the site reconnaissance, no evidence of existing underground or aboveground storage tanks
was observed on the site or on the accessible areas of the adjacent properties. The vegetation on the
site shows no obvious signs of abnormal biological stress, which can be an indicator of subsurface
contamination. No pits, ponds, or lagoons were observed on the site, nor were there any pools of
suspect liquids on the site. No discernible odors were noticed at the site. At the time of the site visit,
no Asbestos-Containing Building Materials (ACBMs) were observed on the site, including those that
On the adjacent parcel to the north, a PG&E-owned pole-mounted transformer was observed
approximately 1,400 feet from the project site. On this same parcel, a large, abandoned, empty
metal container was observed. The soil and plants surrounding this container did not appear to be
stained, disturbed, or stressed. Union Pacific Railroad lines are located approximately 15 to 20 feet
Because the project site was in agricultural production before the use of DDT and certain other toxic
chemicals was banned in 1972, 15 areas of the site were sampled for hazardous materials. Samples
were collected from near surface sample locations. All samples were collected in glass jars and
transported to a state-certified laboratory to be analyzed for organochlorine and organohalide
pesticides (including DDD, DDT, and DDE), lead, and arsenic.
No pesticides or arsenic were detected in any of the samples collected on the project site. Only low
concentrations of lead, below the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) mandated Preliminary
As part of the Phase I Site Assessment, a search of applicable regulatory databases was completed to
identify properties with documented environmental releases and/or those that use, store, or dispose of
regulated chemicals. The identification of contaminated or hazardous materials sites is important to
avoid potential land use compatibility and public safety impacts. The project site is not listed on any
of the databases searched as part of the Phase I report. One leaking underground storage tank was
documented on a site within one-half mile north of the project site. This site is a gas station located
at 19490 Monterey Road. A waste oil tank and surrounding soil was removed from that site and the
case has been closed. While the report describes that the aquifer was affected, the site is located
downgradient of the groundwater flow in the project area. Therefore, it is unlikely that this leak has
The “Geotracker” database, maintained by the State Water Resources Control Board, lists sites with
leaking underground tanks, underground tank wells, as well as some landfills. This database includes
approximately 115 sites in Morgan Hill, many of which are located in the downtown area along the
Monterey Road corridor. As of July 2009, the project site was not listed on local or state databases
[i.e., State Water Resources Control Board (Geotracker) or the Santa Clara County leaking
underground tank program] as a hazardous materials site where there is known contamination.

The project proponent proposes a General Plan amendment to change the land use designation on the
site from Public Facilities to Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre)
the future development of up to 150 single-family units on the site. As previously described, there is
no indication of past use of hazardous materials on the project site. Only low levels of lead were
found during sub-surface testing, which were well below the EPA mandated PRG values. Therefore,
excavation of soil on the site related to future residential development is not expected to result in
health risks to construction workers and/or the public.
The project site is located within one-half mile of a recorded hazardous materials site. While the
aquifer was affected by a leaking waste oil tank, the recorded site is located down-gradient from the
project site and the case has been closed. Therefore, it is not expected that the project site would be
affected by the waste oil leak.

page.text: Many of the policies in the City’s General Plan were adopted for the purpose of avoiding or

future development is subject to General Plan policies, including the following, which will reduce or
avoid risk from exposure to soil contamination:
Hazardous Materials Policy 3t – Provide mitigation to remedy the effects of new or
expanding development over areas with environmental contamination of any and all
Implementation of the General Plan policies and standard measures discussed above would reduce or
avoid possible exposure to residual agricultural chemicals at the time of possible future development.
Portions of the following discussion are based in part upon a hydrology report completed for the
MHCHS FEIR in June 2001, by Schaaf & Wheeler, Consulting Civil Engineers, a memo dated
September 14, 2001 from Schaaf & Wheeler, Consulting Civil Engineers, and a drainage report
completed for the MHCHS FEIR in September 2001, by MH Engineering.
The project site is located in the Fisher Creek watershed. Runoff from the project site currently
drains into Fisher Creek, which runs along the western boundary of the project site, adjacent to Hale
Avenue. The site is relatively flat and slopes gently downward towards the creek and Hale Avenue.
In the vicinity of the project site Fisher Creek is a roadside drainage, ranging between five and eight
feet in width at the base and is about five feet deep. The project site is undeveloped, and, as a result,
the runoff rates from the site during storm events are low.
According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s (FEMA) Flood Insurance Rate Map
, the flood designation for the majority of the project site is shown as Zone D, "areas of
undetermined, but possible, flood hazards". A portion of the property near the southern end of the
site is shown as Zone B, "areas between limits of the 100-year flood and 500-year flood; or certain
areas subject to 100-year flooding with average depths less than one (1) foot or where the
contributing drainage area is less than one square mile".
During a 100-year flood event, Fisher Creek receives floodwaters from four contributing areas, as
overflows from West Little Llagas Creek,
outflow from the Morgan Hill Business Park detention basin,
outflow from the Sutter Business Park detention basin, and
runoff from the upstream portion of the Fisher Creek watershed.
The existing creek does not have sufficient capacity to carry the 100-year peak discharge. During a
100-year flood event, both banks of the creek would be overtopped and the floodplain for the creek
would extend onto Hale Avenue to the west and onto the project site to the east.
An updated FIRM for the project area went into effect on May 18, 2009 (Federal Emergency Management
Agency, Flood Insurance Rate Map, Community Panel Number 06085C 0443H). This FIRM does not include flood
zone designations on the project site, but does show designations in the immediate vicinity to the north, south, and
east. The area surrounding the site is designated as Zone X, which is defined as “Areas of 0.2% annual chance of
flood; areas of 1% annual chance of flood with average depths of less than 1 foot or with drainage areas less than 1
square mile; and areas protected by levees from 1% annual chance flood.” It is likely that much of the project site
would be designated Zone X if the FIRM is updated to include the site. South of the site, the updated FIRM
designates areas in and around Hale Avenue as Zone AH, which is a 100-year flood zone with “Flood depths of 1 to
3 feet (usually areas of ponding); Base Flood Elevations determined.” It is possible that this designation would
continue to the western border of the project site. Flood zone designations related to the portion of Fisher Creek
located adjacent to the project site are also not shown on this FIRM.
Source: Federal Emergency Management Agency, Flood Insurance Rate Map, Community Panel Number 060337
Dams located near Morgan Hill include Anderson Dam and Chesbro Dam. According to the
Association of Bay Area Governments (ABAG), almost all of the Valley Floor terrain in Morgan Hill
is within the area that would be inundated if these dams were to fail with reservoirs at full capacity.
The “worst case” flood of the entire valley is very unlikely, given that it would require both failure
and full capacity conditions to occur at the same time. The project site is located in the dam failure
A seiche is defined as a wave generated by rapid displacement of water within a reservoir or lake,
due to an earthquake that triggers land movement within the water body or landsliding into or
beneath the water body. The project site is not located near a water body that is susceptible to seiche
The site is located within an area in the City of Morgan Hill with recorded groundwater levels of 15
The site is unpaved and undeveloped. The primary non-point source pollutants from the site would
be sediment and plant debris. Storm water runoff from the project site and surrounding area is
released into Fisher Creek. Fisher Creek is a tributary of Coyote Creek, which flows north and
eventually drains to the San Francisco Bay.
The water quality of ponds, creeks, streams, and other surface water-bodies can be greatly affected
by pollution carried in contaminated surface runoff. Pollutants from unidentified sources, known as
“non-point” source pollutants, are washed from streets, construction sites, parking lots, and other
exposed surfaces into storm drains. Stormwater runoff often contains contaminants such as oil and
grease, plant and animal debris (e.g., leaves, dust, animal feces, etc.) pesticides, litter, and heavy
metals. In sufficient concentration, these pollutants have been found to adversely affect the aquatic
The State Water Resources Control Board (SWRCB) is responsible for implementation of the
National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) Program. The Central Coast RWQCB
issues and enforces NPDES permits for discharges to water-bodies in the portion of Santa Clara
County that drains to the Monterey Bay. Projects disturbing more than one acre of land during
construction are required to file a Notice of Intent (NOI) to be covered under the State NPDES
General Construction Permit for discharges of storm water associated with construction activities.
The State NPDES General Construction Permit requires development and implementation of a Storm
Water Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP) and uses storm water Best Management Practices (BMPs)
to control runoff, erosion, and sedimentation from the site both during and after construction. The
ABAG compiled the dam failure inundation hazard maps submitted to the State Office of Emergency Services by
dam owners throughout the Bay Area.
Association of Bay Area Governments, Dam Failure Inundation Hazard Map for Morgan Hill, 1995.
Source: Pacific Geotechnical Engineering, Generalized Hydrogeologic and Liquefaction Potential Map of Valley
Floor Terrain, City of Morgan Hill, December 1991.
